questions.text: Choose the false statement regarding the following instrument which is used for visual field charting.

choices.text: It can evaluate both peripheral as well as central fields
24-2 pattern is most commonly used to assess glaucoma
It uses kinetic method of perimetry

questions.solution:
The given image shows a Humphrey visual field analyzer. It is an automated test that uses the static method of perimetry i.e. the location of a stimulus remains fixed, with intensity increased until it is seen by the subject (threshold is reached) or decreased until it is no longer detected.

It can evaluate both peripheral as well as the central field. (option A)

It is most commonly used in interpreting visual field defects in glaucoma, and other neurological lesions.

Central visual fields are most commonly tested.

  1. Central 24-2 test
    • Most commonly used to assess glaucoma (Option B)
    • 54 points are examined in the central 24 degrees.
    • '24’ denotes the extent in degrees to which the field is tested on the temporal side (to 30° on the nasal side). The number after the hyphen (2) describes the pattern of the points tested.
  2. Central 30-2 test
    • Most comprehensive form of visual field assessment of the central 30 degrees.
    • It consists of 76 points 6 degrees apart on either side of the vertical and horizontal axes, such that the inner most points are three degrees from the fixation point.
  3. Central 10-2 test.
    • Assess 68 points 2 degrees apart in the central 10 degree are examined.
    • Especially used to monitor advanced glaucoma.
  4. Macular grid test 
    • Assess the central 5 degrees.
    • Examines 10 points spaced on a 29 degree square grid centred on the point of fixation.

Perimetry: Visual field charting

Classification:

  • Manual: Confrontation, Listers, Campimetry, Goldmann perimeter
  • Automated: Octopus, Field Master, Humphrey Field Analyzer
  • Static: Friedman, Automated
  • Kinetic: Confrontation, Listers, Scotometry, Goldmann

The best type is automated perimetry.

questions.text: A 56-year-old construction worker came with complaints of reduced vision in his right eye. He gave a history of right eye trauma during his work 1 year ago. On examination, visual acuity of his left eye was 6/5 but in his right eye, it was reduced to the perception of light. His left eye has a blue iris and his right eye has a brownish-green iris. Slit-lamp examination of his right eye revealed a healed corneal wound, posterior to which was a traumatic iris defect suggesting an old penetrating injury. Furthermore, he had a dense cataract, which precluded a view of the posterior segment. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a patient with a previous penetrating eye injury in a construction site presenting with decreased visual acuity, iris heterochromia, and cataract are suggestive of the presence of an intraocular iron foreign body- Siderosis bulbi.

Siderosis bulbi refers to the ocular degenerative changes produced by an iron foreign body. It usually occurs 2 months to 2 years after the injury. This condition is due to the electrolytic dissociation of the metal by an intrinsic resting current in the eye which disseminates the metal, combining it with cellular proteins and causes atrophy.

In siderosis bulbi, 

  1. Iris: first stained greenish and later turns reddish-brown, causing heterochromia iridis.
  2. Pupil: iron deposition in sphincter leads to mydriasis.
  3. Lens: iron deposition in a radial fashion on the anterior capsule of the lens, leading to anterior capsular cataract.
  4. Retina: pigmentary retinopathy; followed by atrophy of the retina and retinal pigmentary epithelium.
  5. Secondary open-angle Glaucoma: due to damage to the trabecular meshwork.

 

Option A: Sympathetic ophthalmitis (SO) is a bilateral granulomatous panuveitis occurring after penetrating trauma which usually begins 4–8 weeks after the injury to the eye (the exciting eye). It is a delayed hypersensitivity reaction mediated by T cells. The exciting eye is often red and irritable, and the sympathizing eye may develop irritation, blurred vision, photophobia, and loss of accommodation.


Option C: Chalcosis refers to the specific changes produced by the alloy of copper in the eye. Clinical features include the following:

  • Kayser–Fleischer ring- a golden brown ring that occurs due to the deposition of copper in the Descemet’s membrane of the cornea.
  • Sunflower cataract- produced by the deposition of copper under the anterior capsule of the lens. It is brilliant golden-green in color and arranged like the petals of a sunflower.

Option D: Phthisis bulbi (Stage of Atrophic bulbi with disorganization) is the end stage of any form of chronic uveitis in which the eye becomes soft, shrink, and atrophic. Due to continued disorganization of the ciliary body:

  • IOP - decreased
  • Size of the eyeball - decreased, 
  • Cornea - sclerosed.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presented with severe pulsatile proptosis, chemosis, diplopia, and an orbital bruit in the left eye three weeks after a motor vehicle accident. He also complains of headaches and tinnitus on the left side. The intraocular pressure in the left eye was increased. What is the investigation of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with pulsatile proptosis, chemosis, and a bruit is suggestive of traumatic carotid-cavernous fistula. Selective catheter digital subtraction angiography is the investigation of choice.


A carotid cavernous fistula is an arteriovenous fistula communicating between the internal carotid artery and the cavernous sinus.
Causes: 

  • Severe head trauma (most common in males) 
  • Degenerative vessels (atheromatous or syphilitic disease) without discoverable trauma, especially in women

Types: 

  1. Direct fistula: 
    • High-flow shunts in which carotid artery blood passes directly into the cavernous sinus through a defect in the wall of the intracavernous portion of the internal carotid artery 
  2. Indirect fistula 
    • Dural shunt/ low flow shunt in which the arterial blood flows through the meningeal branches of the external or internal carotid arteries indirectly into the cavernous sinus. Clinical manifestations are subtler than in a direct fistula.


Presentation:

It presents within days or weeks following trauma; usually ipsilateral to the fistula but may be bilateral, or even contralateral.

The classical triad of presentation is pulsatile proptosis, chemosis, and bruit. 

  1. Marked epibulbar vascular dilatation - “Corkscrew vessels”
  2. Chemosis
  3. Pulsatile proptosis associated with a bruit and a thrill
  4. Increased IOP 
  5. Anterior segment ischemia, characterized by corneal epithelial edema, aqueous cells, and flare and in severe cases iris atrophy, cataract, and rubeosis iridis.
  6. Ophthalmoplegia (III-VI nerve palsies)
  7. Ophthalmoscopy findings: optic disc swelling, venous dilatation, and intraretinal hemorrhage from venous stasis, and impaired retinal blood flow.
  8. Visual loss
    • Immediate - due to ocular or optic nerve damage
    • Delayed - as a result of exposure keratopathy, secondary glaucoma, central retinal vein occlusion, anterior segment ischemia, or ischaemic optic neuropathy.

Investigations:

  • Selective catheter Digital subtraction angiography is the investigation of choice.
  • CT and MRI angiography can also be done


Treatment: mostly conservative. Embolization during arteriography is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman with rheumatoid arthritis presented with mild irritation in her left eye. The ocular examination revealed a necrotic scleral plaque as shown below. Which of the following is not true regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is a necrotising scleritis without inflammation
It is associated with connective tissue diseases.

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of scleromalacia perforans. Spontaneous perforation occurs rarely in this condition as the integrity is maintained by a thin layer of fibrous tissue.

Scleromalacia perforans is a specific type of necrotizing scleritis without inflammation, characterized by progressive scleral thinning. It is typically seen in elderly women with long-standing rheumatoid arthritis. It presents with mild irritation of the eyes. It is a painless condition and has no visual defects. On examination, necrotic scleral plaques may be seen near the limbus, which may coalesce and enlarge. 

It is also associated with other systemic diseases, especially connective tissue diseases. The associated collagen disorders are as follows:

  • Wegener’s granulomatosis
  • Polyarteritis nodosa
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Relapsing polychondritis

Medical management includes steroids and immunosuppressants. In severe cases, surgical treatment by scleral patch graft may be done. 

Related Pearl: Important drugs for rheumatoid arthritis

1) NSAIDs - analgesic and anti-inflammatory, used as adjunctive for management of uncontrollable symptoms and in acute flares.

2) Glucocorticoids - used in acute flare for rapid control and as initial therapy before the onset of action of DMARDs. Chronic administration of low doses is needed in patients with inadequate response to DMARDs.

  • Prednisolone - oral

  • Triamcinolone - intraarticular
     

3) DMARDs - disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs:

 

- Conventional DMARDs:

  • Methotrexate (MTX)- is an antifolate drug. The DMARD of choice and the anchor drug for combination therapy. Regular LFT monitoring is required.
  • Hydroxychloroquine- is used as monotherapy for early and mild disease and in combination with other DMARDs for severe cases.
  • Sulfasalazine- is a salicylate. It reduces the radiographic progression of the disease.
  • Leflunomide- is a pyrimidine synthase inhibitor used as an alternative to MTX.

- Biologicals:

  • TNF-α antagonists- used in combination with MTX. Has a risk of serious bacterial infections, opportunistic fungal infection & reactivation of latent TB. The TNF-α inhibitors are adalimumab, golimumab, etanercept, infliximab, and certolizumab.
  • Abatacept- a T-cell costimulation inhibitor, used in combination with MTX, leflunomide, etc.
  • Rituximab- an anti-CD20 antibody. Used in refractory disease in combination with MTX.
  • Anakinra- an IL-1 receptor antagonist. It should not be combined with anti-TNF alpha.
  • IL-6 receptor antagonists- tocilizumab and sarilumab are used as monotherapy or combination therapy in moderate to severe disease.  

- Small molecules: 

  • Janus kinase inhibitors: Tofacitinib, baricitinib, and upadacitinib are used as monotherapy or combination therapy.

Related Pearl: The 'most commons' of rheumatoid arthritis

Feature of RA Most common  
Involved joints MCP, Wrist, PIP(DIP spared) 
Spine involvement Cervical spine
Extra-articular manifestation Subcutaneous nodules (mostly extensor surface)
Cardiac manifestation Pericarditis
Valvular abnormality Mitral regurgitation
Pulmonary manifestation Pleuritis
Hematological manifestation Normochromic normocytic anemia
Neurological manifestation Compression neuropathies (mostly carpal tunnel syndrome)
Ocular manifestation  Keratoconjunctivitis sicca
Lymphoma Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma
Cause of death Cardiovascular disease (coronary artery disease)

 

 

Related Pearl: Deformities in rheumatoid arthritis

Boutonnière deformity: Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint. 

 

Swan-neck deformity: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint.

 

Z line deformity: Radial deviation of the wrist with ulnar deviation of digits. 

Eversion at hindfoot (subtalar joint), hallux valgus (shown below), hammertoe.

Windswept deformities of toes - Valgus deformities of toes in one foot and varus in the other foot. 

Piano-key movement of the ulnar styloid. 

Trigger finger due to flexor tendon synovitis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with complaints of redness of his eye which started 3 days ago. He has no pain, no discharge, and no complaints about his vision. There was no history of trauma. His blood pressure is 126/84 mmHg. He is not on any anticoagulants. The eye appears as shown in the image below. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
The image given above shows a subconjunctival hemorrhage in the eye. Blood gets absorbed gradually in 1-3 weeks' time without treatment. Hence, reassurance to the patient is the most appropriate management.

A subconjunctival hemorrhage is also called subconjunctival ecchymosis. It is due to the rupture of small blood vessels and can occur spontaneously in elders with fragile vessels, those with systolic hypertension, or after local trauma. The condition is usually associated with a benign course.

It appears as a flat sheet of homogeneous bright red color with well-defined limits. The vision is usually unaffected. Recurrent episodes warrant investigations for a bleeding diathesis or leukemia. 

Spontaneous resolution is typical. The use of NSAIDs and aspirin to treat the condition should be avoided.

Other options:

Option A: CT scan of the head would be appropriate if the patient gives a history of trauma, which raises a suspicion of skull/orbit fracture.

Option B: Anti-hypertensive therapy would be given if the patient has high blood pressure. 

Option D: INR levels will be checked if the patient is on any anticoagulant medication or if there are recurrent episodes.

questions.text: A young woman presented with complaints of difficulty in vision for the past 2 weeks. She has been unable to see cars coming on the right of her car. She has difficulty with right-sided vision in both eyes. On examination, there is a deficit in the right half of her visual field in both eyes. Which of the following in the image below is likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
The patient is having a visual deficit in the right vision i.e right homonymous hemianopia. The structure marked 3 i.e. the left optic tract is likely to be affected. 

In the given scenario, vision is lost in the right half of both eyes, which means:

  • In the left eye, the nasal visual field is lost, and
  • In the right eye, the temporal visual field is lost.

It means left temporal and right nasal fibres are destroyed which leads to right homonymous hemianopia. Anatomically, this can be explained by the fact that each optic tract contains fibres from the ipsilateral temporal half of the retina and the contralateral nasal half of the retina.

Homonymous hemianopia (HH) involves loss of vision on the same side of the visual field in both eyes. It is characteristically seen in lesions involving the visual pathway posterior to the optic chiasma.

HH may be either:

  • Complete HH is characterised by the loss of the entire hemifield on the same side in both eyes
  • Incomplete HH is characterised by partial loss of visual field on the same side in both eyes. Depending on whether the extent of partial loss of the visual field in both the eyes is the same or different, incomplete HH is classified as congruous or incongruous respectively. 

Other options:

Option A: The structure marked as 1 is the left optic nerve. A lesion in this part leads to blindness in the left eye.

Option B: The structure marked as 2 is the right optic nerve. A lesion in this part leads to blindness in the right eye.

Option D: The structure marked as 4 is the right optic tract. A lesion in this part leads to left homonymous hemianopia.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: A 62-year-old female patient reports painless decreased vision in her left eye associated with a “black spot” close to the center of her vision for 2 months. Peripheral vision is normal. Her medical history includes hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. On examination, her visual acuity is significantly reduced in both eyes (left more than right). Amsler grid test shows wavy lines in the central part of the grid. Fundus examination revealed the following findings. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests painless progressive visual loss over months, central scotoma, and the fundoscopic image show sub-retinal hemorrhage near the macula. These features are suggestive of exudative/wet age-related macular degeneration.

In dry/non-exudative age-related macular degeneration, the progression is much slower, over decades. The fundoscopic image would show multiple drusens in the macular area for early dry AMD. For intermediate dry AMD, drusen may appear confluent with significant pigment changes and pigment accumulation. 

The image below shows Drusens in the macular area in Dry macular degeneration.

Age-related macular degeneration (AMD), a degenerative disorder of the macula, is characterized by the presence of drusen and RPE changes. It is the most common cause of permanent central visual loss in the elderly.

Risk factors:
  • Age
  • White race
  • Family history
  • Smoking
  • Hypertension
  • Cardiovascular diseases
  • Obesity
  • Aspirin intake 

Dry (non-exudative, non-neovascular) AMD:

  • The most common form with geographic atrophy (GA) is the advanced stage of dry AMD.
  • No effective treatment is available. Antioxidants like lutein and zeoxanthine are given as prophylaxis.

Wet (exudative, neovascular) AMD:

  • It is much less common than dry but is associated with more rapid progression to advanced sight loss.
  • It is characterized by retinal pigment epithelial detachment and choroidal/subretinal neovascularization.
  • Treatment depends on the location of the choroidal neovascularization membrane.
    • For extrafoveal membrane – laser photocoagulation
    • For subfoveal and juxta foveal treatment options are as follows:
      1. Intravitreal injection of anti-VEGF
      2. Photodynamic therapy – dye used is verteporfin followed by exposure to light from the diode
      3. Transpupillary thermotherapy

questions.text: A newly diagnosed HIV-positive lady with a CD4+ count of 35/μL presented with decreased visual acuity and floaters. On fundus examination, the following findings were seen. Which of the following is true regarding this patient's condition?

choices.text: Screening is done yearly if CD4 counts <100/μl
Anti retroviral therapy is the mainstay of treatment
Valganciclovir is used as intravitreal implant

questions.solution:
The clinical description of an AIDS patient with low CD4 counts with vision abnormalities and the fundus image demonstrating a pizza pie appearance suggests a diagnosis of cytomegalovirus retinitis. Anti-retroviral therapy is the mainstay of treatment.

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis most commonly occurs in immunocompromised states like AIDS, transplant patients, and cancer patients.

Ocular features include reduced vision due to macular involvement, which carries a poor prognosis (Option A). Floaters signify vitritis. One eye is usually affected initially. 

CMV retinitis shows “pizza pie” or “scrambled eggs and ketchup appearance” or “cottage cheese” on fundus examination. It appears as an arcuate zone of retinitis with hemorrhages and optic disc swelling. Often CMV is confined to the retinal periphery, beyond the view of the direct ophthalmoscope. Frosted branch angiitis (FBA) shows marked vascular sheathing. Cataract is a finding in the late stage of the disease.

Highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) is the mainstay of management, restoring the patient’s innate ability to suppress CMV activity. Valganciclovir is taken orally and Ganciclovir is used as a slow-release intravitreal implant. (Option D)

Screening is done in patients with low CD4 counts once in 3 months if <50/μL, once in 6 months if 50–100/μL, and once a year, if >100/μL. (Option B)

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasm

Infections:

  • Protozoal and helminthic infections-
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal infections-
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial infections-
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral infections-
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms:

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix 

Related Pearl: Opportunistic Infections/HIV related conditions and ART initiation

Clinical scenario Action 
Any undiagnosed active infection with fever Diagnose and treat first; start Anti-Retroviral Therapy (ART) when stable
Tuberculosis (TB) Start TB treatment first; start ART as soon as possible after 2 weeks and before 2 months. For those with CD4 less than 50/cmm, start ART within 2 weeks Caution is needed for PLHIV with TB meningitis, since immediate ART is associated with more severe adverse events than initiating ART 2 months after the start of TB treatment

Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP)

 Treat PCP first; start ART when PCP treatment is completed
Invasive fungal diseases: Oesophageal candidiasis, penicilliosis, histoplasmosis Start treatment for oesophageal candidiasis first; start ART as soon as the patient can swallow comfortably. Treat penicilliosis, and histoplasmosis first; start ART when the patient is stabilized or opportunistic infection treatment is completed.
Cryptococcal meningitis Treat cryptococcal meningitis. ART initiation should be deferred until there is evidence of sustained clinical response to anti-fungal therapy and after 4 weeks of induction and consolidation treatment with amphotericin B containing regimen.
Bacterial pneumonia Treat pneumonia first; start ART when treatment is completed
Malaria Treat malaria first; start ART when treatment is completed
Acute diarrhoea which may reduce absorption of ART Diagnose the cause and treat diarrhoea first; start ART when diarrhoea is stabilized or controlled
Non-severe anaemia (Hb< 9 g/dl) Start ART if no other causes for anaemia are found (HIV is often the cause of anaemia) 
Skin conditions such as PPE and seborrhoeic dermatitis, psoriasis, HIV-related exfoliative dermatitis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems) 
Suspected Mycobacterium Avium Complex (MAC), Cryptosporidiosis and Microsporidiosis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems)
Cytomegalovirus retinitis Start treatment for CMV urgently and start ART after 2 weeks of CMV treatment 
Toxoplasmosis Treat toxoplasmosis; start ART after 6 weeks of treatment and when the patient is stabilized

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient came for a regular follow-up. His developmental history was marked by delayed attainment of motor milestones and delay in speech. He has a body mass index (BMI) of 35.9 kg/m2. He was completely blind, had marked central obesity, and polydactyly. The patient's penis and testis were small and hair over the genitalia was sparse. There was no organomegaly on abdominal examination. Neurological examination was normal. Given below is his fundus picture. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The fundus picture has the bony spicule pattern of pigmentation of the retinal periphery, as seen in retinitis pigmentosa. This when combined with truncal obesity, mental retardation, polydactyly, and hypogonadism as given in the clinical scenario is suggestive of Bardet-Biedl syndrome.

The cardinal features of Bardet-Biedl syndrome are

  1. Truncal obesity
  2. Intellectual impairment
  3. Renal anomalies
  4. Polydactyly
  5. Retinal degeneration
  6. Hypogenitalism

 Systemic associations with pigmentary retinal dystrophy:

Usher syndrome (Most common) Sensorineural deafness + RP
Bardet–Biedl syndrome (Previously called Lawrence–Moon–Biedl–Bartum Syndrome)  Polydactyly, obesity, mental handicap, hypogonadism and kidney disease + RP
Kearn–Sayre syndrome Chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia with ptosis + RP
Refsum Syndrome Varied skin as well as neurological and visceral features + RP
Bassen–Kornzweig syndrome Abetalipoproteinemia and acanthocytosis + RP
Neuropathy, ataxia, and retinitis pigmentosa (NARP) Neuropathy and Ataxia + RP

questions.text: A 68-year-old diabetic male patient presented with complaints of diminished vision. The optical coherence tomography (OCT) image is given below. Which of the following findings is likely to be seen on fundus fluorescein angiography of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and OCT image showing intraretinal cystoid spaces are suggestive of cystoid macular edema (CME). Fundus fluorescein angiography image is likely to show a characteristic flower petal pattern (petaloid appearance) in CME.

CME occurs due to a break in the inner and outer blood-retinal barrier. A petaloid pattern is seen due to dye accumulation in microcystic spaces in the outer plexiform layer.

Common causes of CME include uveitis, previous cataract surgery (Irvine-Gass syndrome), retinal vein occlusions, diabetic retinopathy, retinitis pigmentosa, retinopathy of prematurity and topical prostaglandins. Macular edema and cysts may also occur due to niacin toxicity (vitamin B3).

Clinical features in the initial stage include minimal to moderate vision loss. Usually, there are no other associated symptoms. In case of persistent edema, permanent vision loss may occur.

OCT reveals a loss of the foveal depression, thickening of the retina and multiple cystoid areas in the sensory retina. On fundoscopy, the multiple cystoid oval spaces in CME appear as a  "honeycomb appearance". Optic disc swelling may be seen in some cases. A lamellar hole may occur in long-standing cases.

The image below shows the flower petal pattern in CME.

 

Other options:

Option B: A smokestack appearance is a small hyperfluorescent spot that ascends vertically like a smokestack that looks like an umbrella or a mushroom. It is seen in central serous retinopathy (CSR)

 

Option C: Stars in sky appearance is seen in drusens

 

Option D: Inkblot pattern or enlarging dot appearance is a small hyperfluorescent spot that gradually enlarges in size. It is seen in central serous retinopathy (CSR)

choices.text: Localised drying and thinning of cornea

questions.solution:
Dellen is a localized thinning of the peripheral cornea associated with the drying of a focal area. 

Corneal Dellen is small saucer-like excavations at the margin of the cornea. They occur most often following processes that produce a perilimbal elevation that impairs physiological lubrication.

They are most often due to pterygium surgery, large filtration blebs, dermoids, scleritis, episcleritis, scarring after extraocular muscle surgery, or severe conjunctival chemosis.

Patients complain about redness, foreign body sensation, and mild discomfort. The lesions are characterized by an intact epithelium overlying a thinned area of the dehydrated corneal stroma.  

They usually heal within 10–15 days.

Treatment consists of a reduction or elimination of the contributing perilimbal elevation and rapid rehydration with artificial tears, eye ointment, and patching. If treated promptly, Dellen usually resolves completely without any permanent sequelae. 

Image below shows a dellen.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient visited the ophthalmologist for a regular ophthalmic check-up. He has no ocular complaints. His vision is 6/12 in both eyes. His ophthalmic finding is given below. Identify the given condition.
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing a circumferential greyish white corneal band with limbal sparing is suggestive of arcus lipoides/ arcus senilis/ Gerontoxon.

Arcus senilis (AS) is usually an age-related lipid degeneration of the peripheral corneal that forms a light grey or bluish ring. It is the most common peripheral corneal opacity and is usually found in the elderly where it is considered a benign condition.

When AS is found in patients less than 40 years old it is termed arcus juvenilis. It represents an increased risk for cardiovascular disease and warrants screening for an underlying lipid disorder.

AS is caused by leakage of lipoproteins (phospholipids and cholesterol) from limbal capillaries into the corneal stroma.

  • Deposition begins at the superior and inferior aspects and progresses to encircle the entire peripheral cornea which is about 1 mm wide.
  • Peripheral border of this ring opacity is sharp while central border is diffuse.
  • The exterior border of AS and the limbus is separated by a clear zone of the cornea called the interval of Vogt (limbal sparing).

Other options:

Option A: The Kayser- Fleischer (KF) ring is a dark brown ring caused by the deposition of excess copper in the Descemet membrane. It is classically seen in Wilson's disease. It may also be seen in certain chronic, cholestatic liver conditions such as primary biliary cirrhosis. 

The images given below show Kayser–Fleischer ring and sunflower cataract respectively seen in Wilson's disease.

Option C: Limbus sign is caused by dystrophic calcification, seen as a milky precipitate at the corneal limbus. It can sometimes be confused with AS in the elderly population.

Option D: Vogt’s white limbal girdle is a degenerative change seen frequently in elderly people. It appears as bilateral chalky white crescentric opacities in the interpalpebral area both nasally and temporally. Limbal sparing may or may not be there.

Note: Pseudo-gerontoxon is a greyish peri-limbal band of superficial scarring adjacent to a previously inflamed segment of the limbus resembling AS. It is seen in vernal keratoconjunctivitis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old college-going student presents to you with a rapidly increasing power of glasses due to progressive myopia. She has a history of persistent eye rubbing. You also noticed the following sign, when the patient was asked to look in a downward gaze. All the following are treatment options for given condition except?

choices.text: Riboflavin drops, followed by exposure to UV-B radiation

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and lower lid bulging on downgaze (Munson's sign- as shown in the image) is suggestive of keratoconus. Riboflavin drops, followed by exposure to UV-A radiation (not UV-B), is a treatment modality for this condition.

Keratoconus is a progressive bilateral corneal ectatic disorder. It manifests as characteristic cone-like steepening of the cornea associated with irregular stromal thinning, resulting in a cone-like bulge (protrusion) and significant loss of vision.

It is a non-inflammatory disease. With the exception of the significant loss of vision, other classic signs of inflammation are not usually present. The asymmetrical thinning and the highly irregular corneal topography often cause significant myopia and irregular astigmatism. 

Important associations:

  • Rigid contact lens wear
  • Chronic eye rubbing
  • Marfan's, Down’s, EDS syndrome
  • Osteogenesis imperfecta, MVP
  • RP, Leber congenital amaurosis
  • VKC, aniridia, ectopia lentis

Investigations:

  • Corneal topography
  • Pachymetry
  • Keratometry:
    • Steep cornea
    • Bow tie pattern
    • Paracentral thinning of the cornea (thinnest point) 

Treatment:

  • Spectacle correction
  • Rigid gas-permeable contact lens
  • Corneal collagen cross-linking (CXL) - instillation of riboflavin drops to photosensitize the eye, followed by exposure to ultraviolet-A light
  • Intra-corneal ring segments (INTACS)- small curved PMMA ring or set of rings that are implanted in the cornea to help flatten corneal curvature in an effort to improve vision
  • Corneal transplantation- Deep anterior lamellar keratoplasty (DALK) and penetrating keratoplasty (PKP)

Related Pearl: Clinical findings in keratoconus

External signs:

  • Munson’s sign- V-shaped conformation of the lower lid produced by the ectatic cornea in downgaze 
  • Rizzuti’s sign- sharply focused conical beam of light near the nasal limbus, produced by lateral illumination of the cornea from the temporal side

Slit-lamp signs:

  • Vogt’s striae- fine vertical stress lines in the deep stroma, parallel to the steep axis of the cone. May disappear with external pressure on the globe.
  • Fleischer ring- deposition of iron in the epithelium in a ring shape at the base of the conical protrusion.
  • Corneal thinning- predominantly in the inferotemporal area.
  • Hydrops- an acute rupture in Descemet’s membrane causing imbibition of aqueous into the corneal stroma. It is a complication of long-standing keratoconus.
  • Prominent corneal nerves- increased visibility of the corneal nerve fibres.
  • Rupture in Bowman’s layer- irregular superficial opacities that develop due to breaks in Bowman’s layer.

Retroillumination signs:

  • Scissoring reflex- during retinoscopy, two bands of the light beam reflexed from the retina, moves like the blades of the pair of scissors, towards and away from each other. This sign is diagnostic of keratoconus.
  • Oil droplet sign (“Charleaux” sign)- dark reflex in the area of the cone on observation of cornea in dilated pupil by distant direct ophthalmoscopy.

Related Pearl: Vogt's striae

The above image shows “Vogt’s Striae” which are characteristically seen in Keratoconus.

  • Vogt's striae are vertical (rarely horizontal) fine, whitish lines in the deep/posterior stroma and Descemet's membrane commonly found in patients with keratoconus.
  • It may be asymmetric depending on the degree of keratoconus in each eye.
  • It is considered that there is a positive correlation between the orientation of the lines with the steepest axis of the cornea and the mechanism is thought to be related to mechanical stress forces on collagen lamellae radiating from the cone apex.
  • The striae can temporarily disappear with external pressure to the globe.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male patient presents with complaints of foggy vision. He mentions that he cannot read newspapers. He is a heavy tobacco smoker for the past 30 years. Examination revealed a centrocecal scotoma. What is the most important step in the management of this case?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of tobacco-induced optic neuropathy. Complete abstinence from smoking is the most important step in management in this case.

Tobacco-induced optic neuropathy (previously termed toxic amblyopia) is caused by excessive use of tobacco by smoking and chewing. The toxic agent involved is cyanide found in tobacco.

The illustration given below shows the pathogenesis of tobacco-induced optic neuropathy.

It is characterized by bilateral gradually progressive impairment of central vision, and a centrocecal scotoma - a type of central scotoma involving both the blind spot and macula. Fundus examination may be normal or slight temporal pallor of the disc may be seen.

Treatment includes

  • Complete cessation of tobacco and alcohol consumption.
  • Improvement may be hastened by hydroxocobalamin 1000 μg intramuscular injections weekly for 10 weeks. Though intramuscular vitamin B12 injection may hasten the recovery, eliminating the causative factor i.e. tobacco cessation should be the mainstay of treatment. 
  • Nutritional supplements.

Causes of central/centrocecal scotoma

  • Optic neuritis
  • Compressive lesion eg. pituitary adenoma
  • Optic neuropathy due to
    • Poor nutrition
    • Tobacco
    • Alcohol
  • Drug-induced optic neuropathy
  • Toxin-induced optic neuropathy
  • Hereditary optic atrophy
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Leukemia

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presented with severe eye pain, photophobia, and lacrimation in his left eye. He has no significant past history or any systemic illnesses. Visual acuity in the left eye was 6/24. Fluorescein staining of his left eye revealed an ulcer as shown in the image.  On further examination, there was no evidence of trauma or infective etiology. Serology revealed the presence of antibodies against some corneal antigens. Which of the following statements is not true about this condition?

choices.text: Painful superficial ulcer that can perforate
Characterized by a steep, overhanging edge
Ulcer begins peripherally and spreads circumferentially

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with a painful peripheral corneal ulcer with steep, overhanging edges (as shown in image) in a young male patient, with positive autoimmune serology (antibodies against corneal antigen), and exclusion of other etiology for corneal ulcer is suggestive of Mooren Ulcer / Rodent ulcer. Limbus is involved. (not spared)

It is described as a chronic serpiginous ulcer of the cornea. It is a subtype of peripheral ulcerative keratitis (PUK). It is defined as an idiopathic condition without associated systemic or rheumatological conditions and hence is a diagnosis of exclusion. The pathophysiology is thought to be due to autoimmune (antibodies against corneal epithelium).

Clinical features include redness, tearing, and photophobia, but the pain is typically the outstanding feature. There may also be a complaint of decreased visual acuity, which may be secondary to associated iritis or central corneal involvement. 

Two forms:

  • Benign/Limited - unilateral, slowly progressive, elderly
  • Virulent/Progressive - bilateral, aggressive spread, young patient, extremely painful
Signs- Peripheral ulceration involving the superficial one-third of the stroma with variable epithelial loss. An undermined and overhanging edge is characteristic of this ulcer.

Initially, the ulcerative process spreads circumferentially. Later it moves centrally to involve the entire cornea. In contrast to other forms of PUK, the limbus is involved.

The end-stage result is typically a scarred, vascularized cornea that may be thinned to less than half of its original thickness. These ulcers can rarely perforate.

Treatment involves corticosteroids and conjunctival resection, which eliminates the conjunctival sources of inflammatory mediators.  

The image shows a perforated Mooren's ulcer.

questions.text: An ophthalmologist performs the swinging flashlight test, which reveals the findings as shown in the image given below. Which structure is affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
The image above shows Marcus Gunn pupil, which is confirmed by the swinging-flashlight test. The right eye is affected, while the left eye is normal. It is the earliest sign of optic nerve/cranial nerve II disease.

The flashlight is swung to and fro and the pupillary response is observed. Normally, both pupils remain constricted. In the presence of relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), both pupils dilate on moving the flashlight from the normal to the abnormal eye. This paradoxical response of the pupil to light is called Marcus Gunn pupil.

Impaired pupillary constriction due to a defect in the afferent pathway of the pupillary light reflex in one eye, causes a RAPD or a Marcus-Gunn pupil on a swinging flashlight test. 

The image given below shows the swinging flashlight test as seen in a normal person and in a patient with a right relative afferent pupillary defect.

Other abnormal pupillary reactions:

  1. Amaurotic light reflex - On flashing light to the affected eye, there is no direct light reflex in the affected eye, and there is no consensual light reflex in the normal eye. This occurs due to a lesion in the optic nerve or retina.
  2. Efferent pathway defect - Absence of both direct and consensual light reflex on the affected side and presence of both direct and consensual light reflex on the normal side. It occurs due to a defect in the efferent pathway.
  3. Wernicke’s hemianopic pupil -In this condition, light reflex (ipsilateral direct and contralateral consensual) is absent when light is thrown on the temporal half of the retina of the affected side and nasal half of the normal side, while it is present when the light is thrown on the nasal half of the affected side and temporal half of the normal side. It occurs due to a lesion in the optic tract.
  4. Adie’s tonic pupil - In this condition, the light reflex is absent and the response to near reflex is very slow and tonic. The affected pupil is larger than normal (anisocoria). It is caused by postganglionic parasympathetic pupillomotor damage.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presented with complaints of watering from his left eye for the past 6 months. Syringing revealed a patent drainage system. The rest of the ocular examination was normal. A provisional diagnosis of lacrimal pump failure was made. Which of the following tests will help in the confirmation of the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Nuclear lacrimal scintigraphy, also known as dacryoscintigraphy, confirms the diagnosis of lacrimal pump failure.

Lacrimal pump failure means an inability of the lid muscles to push tears towards the punctum for drainage. It is also called functional obstruction.

It gives a negative jones test 1 as well as a negative jones test 2.

Nuclear lacrimal scintigraphy is better than contrast dacryocystography, as the former assesses the lacrimal passage under more physiological conditions.

Flowchart below depicts the Jones dye test.

questions.text: A 65-year-old diabetic male patient came for a regular ophthalmic examination. He has no ocular complaints. A slit-lamp examination revealed the following finding in his right eye. It is also noted that these opacities do not settle down when the eye is immobile and moves with the vitreous during eye movements. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a diabetic, elderly male with unilateral numerous yellowish-white vitreous opacities that don’t sediment when the eye is immobile is suggestive of asteroid hyalosis.

Asteroid hyalosis is a common degenerative process in which calcium pyrophosphate particles collect within the vitreous gel. It is seen clinically as numerous tiny round yellow-white opacities of varying size and density. These move with the vitreous during eye movements but do not sediment inferiorly when the eye is immobile.

It occurs unilaterally (75%); patients are mostly asymptomatic. It is more common in elderly men. Associated with diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia.

Other options-

Option A:  Synchysis scintillans are vitreous opacities that occur as a consequence of chronic vitreous hemorrhage, often in a blind eye. They are composed of cholesterol derived from plasma cells or degraded products of erythrocytes. These vitreal opacities sediment in the lower part of the vitreous cavity due to gravity.

The below image shows Synchysis scintillans.

Option B: Muscae volitantes commonly referred to as ‘floaters’, is an ubiquitous entoptic phenomenon of fly-, cobweb- or thread-like condensations that are best seen against a pale background. It represents tiny embryological remnants in the vitreous gel. 

Image given below show floaters.

Option C: The vitreous opacities in amyloidosis are linear with footplate attachments to the retina and posterior surface of the lens and has a characteristic sheet-like (‘glass wool’) appearance.

questions.text: A young woman presented with ocular pain, photophobia, and blurred vision in her left eye for 10 days. She explains that her symptoms started after she had slept without removing her contact lenses. Her left eye is shown in the image below. Intra-ocular pressure is normal in both eyes. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows localized bulging of the cornea surrounded by a white cicatricial ring suggestive of descemetocele. 

Descemetocele (Keratocele) is a localized bulging of Descemet's membrane. Patients with regular use of contact lenses are at higher risk of developing keratitis. Infections from the organisms like pneumococci, pseudomonas, and other septic organisms destroy all the layers of the cornea except for Descemet's membrane. However, this membrane alone is not able to support the intraocular pressure and therefore herniates. Patients will complain of pain, photophobia, and blurred vision.

The bulging membrane may persist surrounded by a white cicatricial ring or may rupture. It presents with severe pain and is a sign of impending perforation.

 

Other options:

Option A: Healed corneal ulcer will have a visual impairment and irregular opacity on the cornea.

The below image shows healed corneal ulcer.

 

Option C: In perforated corneal ulcers, patients complain of sudden gushing of hot fluid out of the eyes. Following this pain suddenly reduces. On examination, there is corneal opacity, prolapse of the iris, anterior dislocation of the lens, and reduced intraocular pressure.

Option D: Mooren's ulcer is a superficial ulcer that may occur due to autoimmune diseases. It starts as patches of grey infiltrates at the corneal margin. The ulcer then progresses to the whole of cornea.

Below image shows Mooren's ulcer in the periphery of the cornea.

Related Pearl: Clinical differential diagnosis of corneal ulcer

  Bacterial Fungal Viral Parasitic
Risk factors

Contact lens wear

Trauma

Chronic steroid use

Anesthetic cornea

Dry eyes

Exposure keratopathy

 Trauma with vegetative matter

Low immunity

Recurrent attacks

Contact lens wear

Exposure to contaminated water (acanthamoeba)

 
Clinical features

Hypopyon is fluid and mobile

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is likely to have a rapid course, with deep corneal necrosis.

Less pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Tend to be indolent but progressive

Hypopyon is thick, immobile.

Relatively more pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Recurrences are characteristic.

Disproportionately severe pain is a characteristic feature.

Indolent course and in initial stages, often mistaken to be viral/ fungal infection, leading to a delay in diagnosis

questions.text: On routine examination of a neonate, the left eye was smaller in size and had a white pupillary reflex. The fundoscopy image is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis is persistent fetal vasculature.

The points in the clinical vingette pointing to this diagnosis are: 

  • White pupillary reflex in the left eye (unilateral leukocoria)
  • Smaller size of the left eye (microphthalmos) and 
  • Fundoscopy image showing a leash of vascularized fibrous tissue extending from the back of the lens to the optic nerve head

Persistent fetal vasculature was earlier known as persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous. It is the failure of primary vitreous and hyaloid vasculature to regress. This eventually leads to contraction and opacification combined with the hypoplasia of the posterior portion of the vascular meshwork.

It is unilateral in most of the cases. It is bilateral in cases that are associated with Trisomy 13, trisomy 22, Norries disease, and Walkers Warburg syndrome. 

Clinical Findings include:

  1. Leukocoria
  2. Microphthalmia 
  3. Shallow anterior chamber 
  4. Retrolental cataract 
  5. Esotropia 
  6. Angle-closure glaucoma 
  7. Dilated iris vessels 
  8. Persistent hyaloid artery 
  9. Vitreous hemorrhage
  10. Tractional retinal detachment 

Investigations:

  • CT scan of orbit to evaluate for the presence of calcification, which is present in retinoblastoma but absent in persistent fetal vasculature. 
  • B-scan ultrasonography to evaluate for retinal detachment when a cataract limits the view to the retina.

Treatment is done by pars plana lensectomy and vitrectomy to remove the retrolental fibrovascular membrane to prevent angle-closure glaucoma, followed by aggressive amblyopia therapy

Image below shows the falciform fold of detached dysplastic retina encircling the persistent hyaloid artery that extends from the optic nerve head to the retrolental mass.

Option A:

Retinoblastoma is a proliferation of neural cells that have failed to evolve normally. Retinoblastoma arises from the neurosensory retina. Leukocoria and squint are the most common presentation of retinoblastoma. It may also present as painful red eye, cataract, buphthalmos, proptosis(not microphthalmos) and pseudohypopyon.

Option B:

Coats' disease is idiopathic retinal telangiectasia that is generally of onset in early childhood. It presents as unilateral visual loss, leukocoria (because of exudative retinal detachment), and strabismus. It is associated with intraretinal and subretinal exudation. 

The image below shows total retinal detachment with subretinal exudate containing cholesterol crystals and a fibrous nodule in the posterior pole seen in Coats' disease.

Option C:

Retinal detachment refers to the separation of the inner layers of the retina from the underlying retinal pigment epithelium.

Fundus shows smooth and convex (usually round) retinal detachment. Shifting fluid will be seen in exudative type. Shaffer's sign - Pigments in the anterior vitreous (tobacco dusting) is a feature of fresh retinal detachment.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presented with complaints of left eye pain. She has a previous history of vitreoretinal surgery with tamponade for management of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment in the left eye 2 years ago. Her left eye is shown below. What is the finding shown in the image?

choices.text: Collection of pus in the vitreous
Collection of emulsified silicone oil in the anterior chamber

questions.solution:
The image shows reverse hypopyon/ inverse hypopyon/ hyperoleon, which is the collection of emulsified silicone oil in the anterior chamber.

Silicone oil is the vitreous substitute that is injected into the vitreous cavity after vitrectomy. When it gets emulsified, it enters the anterior chamber and collects in the upper part.

Complications of silicone oil in the anterior chamber:

  1. Glaucoma
  2. Band-shaped keratopathy

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presented with watering, pain, and photophobia in his left eye for the past 6 weeks. He reported having similar episodes in the past. The results of fluorescein staining of his left eye are shown in the image below. Which of the following is not true regarding the patient's condition?

choices.text: It is caused by herpes simplex virus (HSV).
Antivirals are the first line of therapy.
It is a linear branching ulcer with tapered ends.

questions.solution:
The above image shows a dendritic corneal ulcer, which is an irregular, zigzag linear branching ulcer with knobbed ends (not tapered ends) as seen in the image as well.

A dendritic corneal ulcer is pathognomonic of the herpes simplex infection.

Herpetic simplex keratitis, also known as herpetic keratoconjunctivitis and herpes viral keratitis, is a form of keratitis caused by recurrent herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection in the cornea. (Option A)

Signs & Symptoms:

  • The classic herpetic lesion consists of a linear branching corneal ulcer (dendritic ulcer). The ulcer is initially superficial and spreads in all directions as grey striae, which extend and increase in length. 
  • Patients with epithelial keratitis complain of foreign-body sensation, light sensitivity, redness, and blurred vision associated with focal or diffuse reduction in corneal sensation. (Option B)
  • In patients who are immunocompromised due to pre-existing disease or using corticosteroids, the ulcer may become large; in such cases, the lesion is called a geographic ulcer.
  • Stromal keratitis manifests as a disc-shaped area of corneal edema.

Treatment:

Topical antivirals are the first-line treatment. (Option C)

  • Trifluorothymidine 1% drops four times a day for 5 days, acyclovir 3% ointment five times a day for 21 days, or 3% vidarabine ointment five times a day for 2 weeks
  • Systemic antivirals in cases of increased severity or recurrence
  • Topical antibiotics to prevent secondary bacterial infection

Related Pearl: Ocular lesions of Herpes Simplex

Primary herpes:

  • Cornea
    • Fine epithelial punctate keratitis
    • Coarse epithelial punctate keratitis
    • Dendritic ulcer
  • Conjunctiva: acute follicular conjunctivitis
  • Skin lesions

Recurrent herpes:

  • Active epithelial keratitis
    • Punctate epithelial keratitis
    • Dendritic ulcer
    • Geographical ulcer
  • Stromal keratitis
  • Disciform keratitis
  • Diffuse stromal necrotic keratitis
  • Trophic keratitis (meta-herpetic)
  • Herpetic iridocyclitis

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presented with complaints of foreign body sensation, irritation, and watering from his left eye for the past 6 months. His past history is significant for a chemical burn injury to his left eye 1 year ago. Ocular examination revealed an inturned upper lid margin in his left eye. Which of the following operations is used to correct this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with an inturned upper lid margin along with past history of chemical burns injury is suggestive of cicatricial entropion. Modified Ketssey’s operation is done to correct cicatricial entropion.

Modified Ketssey’s operation- Transposition of Tarso-conjunctival wedge

It involves tarsal fracture and eversion of distal tarsus. 

  1. A horizontal incision is made along the whole length of sulcus subtarsalis (2–3 mm above the lid margin) involving the conjunctiva and tarsal plate 
  2. The lower piece of the tarsal plate is undermined up to the lid margin. 
  3. Mattress sutures are then passed from the uppercut end of the tarsal plate to emerge on the skin 1 mm above the lid margin 
  4. When sutures are tied the entropion is corrected by transposition of  tarso-conjunctival wedge 

All other options (Weis operation, Jones operation, Quickert Procedure) are done to correct senile entropion.

Senile entropion

Anterior lamellar resection

Transverse everting suture

Tarsal wedge resection

Weiss operation

Transposition of the tarsoconjunctival wedge. (Modified Ketssey’s operation)

Plication of lower lid retractors (Jones operation).

Posterior lamellar graft

questions.text: The test given in the following image is _____.
questions.solution:
The above image shows the Farnsworth–Munsell 100-hue test, which is used to test color vision.

The Farnsworth–Munsell 100-hue test:

  • It is a spectroscopic test.
  • It consists of 85 caps of different hues in four racks and the subject is asked to rearrange the colored chips in ascending order.
  • It is the most sensitive test for both congenital and acquired color vision defects. 
  • An error score is used to judge the color vision, i.e. greater the score poorer will be the color vision.

Note:

Farnsworth D15 hue discrimination test is similar to the above test but it utilizes only 15 hue caps.

  • Ishihara’s plates

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presents with left eyelid swelling for the past two days and denies any history of ocular trauma. He reports that he had a mild flu-like illness one week back for which he took some medications. He is febrile. Ophthalmic examination reveals normal visual acuity with no ophthalmoplegia and no proptosis.  What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette with eyelid swelling and fever following an infection without proptosis, and ophthalmoplegia with normal visual acuity are suggestive of preseptal cellulitis/ periorbital cellulitis.

Preseptal cellulitis is an infection of the subcutaneous tissues anterior to the orbital septum. The commonly implicated bacteria include Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus pyogenes.

The mode of spread of infection can occur through skin trauma, insect bites, acute hordeolum, dacryocystitis, conjunctivitis, sinusitis, Upper respiratory tract infection, and middle ear infection.

Clinical features include,

  • Tender, firm, erythematous eyelid swelling
  • Conjunctiva - usually no chemosis
  • Proptosis - absent
  • Ocular movements - normal
  • Visual acuity - normal
  • Systemic symptoms: fever, leucocytosis

Treatment: 

  • Antibiotics - oral or i.v depending on severity.
  • Systemic analgesics
  • Warm compresses

Complications include spread of infection and may develop into orbital cellulitis, abscess formation, meningitis, cavernous sinus thrombosis.

Option A:  Endophthalmitis is the inflammation of the inner coats of the eye due to intraocular colonization of infectious agents. There is exudation within intraocular fluids. It generally occurs after trauma, surgery, or due to an endogenous source. It is characterized by poor visual acuity, corneal edema, hypopyon, vitreous inflammation, and poor fundus visualization. 

Option B: Orbital cellulitis refers to the acute infection of the contents of the orbit behind the orbital septum. Features include:

  • Pain, lid edema, erythema, chemosis, and axial proptosis.
  • Increased pain with movement of eyes and ophthalmoplegia (decreased ocular motility) is a classic symptom
  • A rapid loss of vision is due to the involvement of the optic nerve, diplopia.
  • Systemic symptoms include malaise and fever.
The image shown below is of a patient with orbital cellulitis and orbital apex syndrome presenting with complete ptosis, proptosis, total ophthalmoplegia, chemosis, and congestion.

Option D- Lid tumors can be variable in etiology. A few examples include squamous papilloma (raspberry-like growth), eyelid actinic keratosis (yellow plaque-like lesions), or capillary hemangiomas (bright red colored lesions over the eyelids).

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy comes with complaints of diminished vision. On examination, the macula shows a ‘beaten-bronze’ appearance. Furthermore, visual fields show a central loss. The choroid is characteristically ‘dark’ in fluorescein angiography. All of the following about this disease are true except:

choices.text: Vitamin A supplementation should be given
Accumulation of lipofuscin within retinal pigment epithelium
It is inherited in autosomal recessive pattern

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of Stargardt disease. Vitamin A supplementation is avoided as it may accelerate lipofuscin accumulation.

Stargardt disease/ fundus flavimaculatus is the most common type of macular dystrophy occurring in childhood or adolescence. It is commonly inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern due to mutation in the ABCA4 gene. It is characterized by the accumulation of lipofuscin within the retinal pigment epithelium(RPE). 

Macular signs

  • May initially be normal, later progressing to an oval ‘snail slime’ or ‘beaten-bronze’ appearance and subsequently to geographic atrophy.
  • Numerous yellow-white round, oval or fish-shaped lesions at the level of the RPE.

Investigations:

  • Visual fields show a central loss.
  • Electroretinography - Pattern ERG is completely extinguished while full-field ERG may remain normal.
  • FFA- Dark choroid, the macula shows mixed hyper and hypofluorescence.
  • Indocyanine green angiography (ICGA) shows hyperfluorescent spots.

Image A shows the fundus with macular yellow flecks and B shows the angiofluoresceingraphy (AFG) of the silent choroid and atrophic retinal pigment epithelium at the macular area.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of the condition seen in the image?
questions.solution:
The above image depicting a wing shaped encroachment of conjunctiva onto the cornea is suggestive of Pterygium.

Pterygium is a triangular fibrovascular ingrowth that is seen following an elastotic degeneration of the subconjunctival tissue. The apex of the pterygium lies towards the cornea. The pterygium is usually seen on the nasal side in the palpable aperture and can give rise to symptoms such as foreign body sensation in the eye, diplopia and defective vision due to corneal astigmatism. In some cases, iron deposition can be seen in the corneal epithelium anterior to the advancing head of the pterygium known as the stocker’s line.

Pterygium can be left untreated if there is no visual impairment. In cases with impaired vision, procedures such as surgical excision with free conjunctival limbal graft & surgical excision with amniotic membrane graft and mitomycin-C can be done.

Option A: Pinguecula is an asymptomatic yellow-white mound of degenerated collagen fibers of the conjunctival stroma. It more commonly starts on the nasal limbus and can later be seen on the temporal side. The apex of the Pinguecula is directed away from the cornea. It is mostly a stationary condition, so no treatment is usually required. If inflamed, topical steroids can be applied.

 

Option C: Chemical burns are caused by alkalis and acids. In mild-moderate burns, the end result is corneal ulceration followed by opacification. Severe burns result in sloughing of the whole cornea followed by staphyloma formation. Complications of chemical burns include symblepharon where the palpebral & bulbar conjunctiva are fused.

Option D: Thermal burns from fire & hot fluids mainly affect the lids. Cornea & conjunctiva will be affected in severe cases.

questions.text: The electroretinogram (ERG) of a person is given below. In this ERG, wave B is due to?
questions.solution:
The image shown is a normal electroretinogram (ERG) in which wave B is due to Muller cells.

Electroretinography measures the changes in the resting potential of an eye, induced by the light stimulus. Waves of ERG include a,b and c. Among these, a and c are negative waves and b is a large positive wave as shown below. The c wave is only seen in the dark-adapted eye. 

Uses of ERG:

  • Diagnosis and prognosis of retinal disorders
  • Early detection of functional abnormalities of the outer retina up to the bipolar cell layer
  • Assessment of retinal function in babies with possible impaired vision and in cases where fundus examination is difficult (in the presence of dense cataracts and corneal opacity).
  • Focal ERG is used to evaluate the diseases of the macula.

Note: Diseases involving ganglion cell layer and higher visual pathways may show a normal ERG.

Abnormal ERG response:

  • Subnormal b-wave response is seen in early cases of retinitis pigmentosa.
  • Extinguished response is seen when there is a complete failure of rods and cones function e.g., advanced retinitis pigmentosa, complete retinal detachment, central retinal artery occlusion.
  • A negative response is seen in gross disturbances of the retinal circulation.

questions.text: The ophthalmologic instrument shown in the image is not used for:
questions.solution:
The image shows a stenopaic slit. It is not used in corneal tattooing.

It can be used to: 

  • Determine the axis of the cylinder in astigmatism.
  • In cases with corneal opacity, the optimal site for optical iridectomy is determined using a stenopaic slit
  • Perform Fincham's Test

Related Pearl: Fincham’s Test

Also called Emsley–Fincham Test

It used for differentiating between the colored halos due to cataract (lenticular) and those in corneal edema due to glaucoma. It is performed by passing a stenopaic slit across the pupil and observing the halos.

Halos are broken up into segments which revolve as the slit moves → Lenticular halo

Intact halos but the intensity and brightness are diminished → Glaucomatous halo

The image shows a stenopaeic slit.

It causes reduced size of blur circle in the meridian perpendicular to the slit and no change in the blur circle in the meridian coincident with it. So, it can be used to determine the axis of the cylinder in astigmatism.

In cases with corneal opacity, the optimal site for optical iridectomy is determined using a stenopaic slit.

questions.text: A man who regularly uses contact lenses comes with complaints of blurred vision and ocular pain. Examination shows radial keratoneuritis as seen below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above presentation of blurred vision and pain, along with the findings of a radial keratoneuritis and ring lesion (seen in the image), suggests a probable diagnosis of acanthamoeba keratitis. 

It is caused by Acanthamoeba spp which are free-living protozoa found in soil, freshwater, and the upper respiratory tract. Contact lens wearers are the most prone to this infection.

Patients complain of blurring of vision and pain is often disproportionate to examination. There are characteristic perineural infiltrates, otherwise known as radial keratoneuritis, are pathognomonic and can be seen during early infection. As the infiltrates grow, they gradually coalesce to form the typical ring abscess.

Staining of the corneal scraping using periodic acid-Schiff or calcofluor white as well as culture is done to diagnose the disease. 

Management includes topical amoebecides, analgesics for pain, as well as debridement of the involved epithelium. Therapeutic keratoplasty is done for resistant cases. 

 The below image shows a hypopyon and typical ring abscess of amebic keratitis.

 

Other options:

Option A: Staphylococcal keratitis usually presents as photophobia, blurred vision, mucopurulent discharge and focal and well-defined white/yellowish-white infiltrate. There are features of anterior uveitis with hypopyon and keratic precipitates.

Option B: Candidal keratitis would present as a typical yellow-white densely suppurative infiltrate. Features of anterior uveitis can also be seen here. 

Option C: Herpes simplex keratitis presents as ocular discomfort, photophobia, and decreased visual acuity. HSV can cause characteristic epithelial (dendritic/geographic) keratitis or disciform keratitis.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions should an ophthalmologist prescribe miotics?
questions.solution:
Miotics are used in the management of accommodative esotropia.

The use of miotics in convergent strabismus is based on the peripheral spasm of accommodation caused by the drug. The accommodation triad involves convergence. An increased accommodative effort increases the amount of convergence. Pilocarpine would produce accommodation spasm and eliminate the accommodative convergence that would otherwise occur when the patient looks at a near object. It is useful in cases of an abnormal AC/A ratio as in, accommodative esotropia.

questions.text: A patient with a history of trauma, presented with diplopia, epistaxis, and restricted eye movements. Looking at the CT image given below, what will be your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario plus the supportive CT image showing the "hanging drop sign" is suggestive of a blowout fracture of the orbital wall.

Blow-out fractures are isolated comminunited fractures caused from direct trauma to the orbit that results in a backward displacement of the eyeball and an increase in the intraorbital pressure. This causes a fracture at the weakest point of the orbital wall which is usually the posteromedial portion of the maxillary bone in the orbital floor. The second most common site for orbital blowout fracture is the medial wall of the orbit.

The patient with blow out fracture usually presents with immediate periorbital edema and blood extravasation in and around the orbit. Proptosis of the eyeball secondary to orbital edema or hemorrhage with paresthesia along the infraorbital nerve are also very common.

Imaging by a plain x-ray in water's view or by CT demonstrates depression of bony fragments and orbital contents herniating through the orbital floor into the maxillary antrum. This is called as the "hanging drop sign" or "tear drop sign".

Definitive treatment is by surgical repair 10-14 days after injury with initial supportive management with analgesics and antibiotics.

Le fort fracture- Is the term used to describe different types of maxillary fractures.

Related Pearl: Le-Fort's classification of Maxillary Fracture

Le-Fort I is a transverse fracture of the maxilla
  • Fracture line passes through the lower part of nasal septum, maxillary antra and the pterygoid plates
  • It separates palate from the rest of the face leading to floating teeth or palate
  • Also called Guerin’s fracture. 
Le-Fort II is a pyramidal fracture
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, lacrimal bone, floor of the orbit, upper part of the maxillary sinus and pterygoid plates
  • X-ray or CT appears like hanging maxilla
  • It is associated with CSF rhinorrhea.
Le-Fort III is craniofacial dysjunction i.e., facial skeleton completely disconnected from its cranial attachment
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, ethmo-frontal junction, superior orbital fissure, lateral wall of the orbit, fronto-zygomatic and temporo-zygomatic sutures and the upper part of pterygoid plates
  • It is also associated with CSF rhinorrhea.

questions.text: A 56-year-old patient who had undergone cataract surgery previously is noted to have the following finding on ocular examination. What is this clinical finding?
questions.solution:
The clinical finding noted in the image above is Soemmering's ring, which is one of the types of after-cataract.

After-cataract is the most common postoperative complication encountered following cataract surgery. Soemmering's ring is defined as a thick ring of after-cataract or secondary cataract that persists or develops after extracapsular cataract extraction.

No treatment is needed if the central posterior capsule is clear. If the central posterior capsule is covered by a thin membrane, YAG-laser capsulotomy or discission with cystitome/Zeigler’s knife is done. If the membrane is thick, surgical membranectomy is needed.

The image given below shows different types of after-cataract.

Other options:

Option A: Vossius' ring is a small ring shaped pigment on the anterior lens capsule. It is caused by the contracted pupillary margin striking against the lens capsule that occurs following blunt trauma.

Option C: Weiss' or Vogt’s ring is seen in posterior vitreous detachment as a ring around the optic disc. This appearance is caused by the attachment of the peripapillary glial tissue to the detached vitreous cortex.

Option D: Fleischer’s ring refers to a brown ring formed by iron deposition around the base of the cone in keratoconus.

Related Pearl: Complications of cataract surgery

Early postoperative complications

Occurs within the first few days to 4 weeks.

  • Endophthalmitis
  • Retained lens matter
  • Corneal edema
  • Wound leak and dehiscence
  • Toxic anterior segment syndrome

Late postoperative complications

Occurs within months to years.

  • Posterior capsule opacification (most common)
  • Cystoid macular edema
  • Secondary glaucoma
  • Retinal detachment
  • Intraocular lens malpositions:
    • Windshield wiper syndrome— intraocular lens haptic rubs on the endothelium
    • Sunset syndrome—inferior subluxation
    • Sunrise syndrome—superior subluxation
    • Complete dislocation of the intraocular lens.

questions.solution:
The given image is that of an enucleation spoon. This is identified by the central cleavage that engages the optic nerve in enucleation.

 

Other options:

Option A- Evisceration spatula consists of a small but stout rectangular blade with a slightly convex surface and blunt edges attached to a handle. It is used to separate out the uveal tissue from the sclera during evisceration operation.

 

Option C- Chalazion clamp consists of two limbs like forceps, which can be clamped with the help of a screw. The tip of one limb is flattened in the
form of a round disc while the tip of the other arm has a small circular ring. It is used to fix the chalazion and achieve hemostasis during the incision and curettage operation.

 

Option D- Bone punch consists of a stout spring handle and two blades attached at a right angle. It is used to enlarge the bony opening during

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with a visual acuity of 6/6 in the right eye and only hand movements in the left eye. On fundoscopy, the right eye appears normal. Left eye fundoscopic appearance is as given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a young boy in his first decade of life with a unilateral decrease in visual acuity with fundus showing telangiectasia and severe lipid deposition points to the diagnosis of Coats' disease.

Coats' disease is a congenital vascular disorder of the eye typically seen in boys in their first decade and is usually unilateral. In children, Coats’ disease is typically diagnosed as a result of recognition of poor vision, strabismus, or leukokoria.

Early stages of ocular manifestations include discrete zones with dilated and tortuous retinal blood vessels and a number of small aneurysms near the posterior pole and around the disc. The ophthalmoscopic picture shows retinal vascular abnormalities associated with large areas of intra and subretinal yellowish exudates and hemorrhages.

Given below is the fundus picture of Coats’ disease showing aneurysmal dilatation, telangiectasia, exudation, and severe macular lipid deposition.

 

Other options:

Option A- Central serous retinopathy is characterized by spontaneous serous detachment of the neurosensory retina in the macular region, with or without retinal pigment epithelium detachment. The fundus findings include mild elevation of the macular area, absent or distorted foveal reflex, and subretinal deposits. The given below is the fundus picture of central serous retinopathy.

 

Option B- Purtscher retinopathy is characterized by multiple retinal white areas around the optic nerve head and fovea (Purtscher flecken), cotton wool spots, and minimal intraretinal hemorrhages. The given below is the fundus picture of Purtscher retinopathy.

 

Option D- Best's disease is a hereditary macular disorder which shows the presence of egg yolk lesion or scrambled egg lesion in the macula. The given below is the fundus picture of Best's disease showing an egg yolk lesion in the macula.

questions.text: A patient with 1.5D myopia undergoes streak retinoscopy. The patient is seated one meter from the light source and is asked to fixate on a distant object as the retinoscopy is performed. With respect to the movement of the plane mirror in the retinoscope, the red reflex in the eye exhibits:
questions.solution:
In a patient with myopia of 1.5D, the red reflex will exhibit movement against the plane mirror.

When a plane mirror retinoscope is used at a distance of 1 meter, based upon the movement of the red reflex, the results can be interpreted as:

  • No movement of red reflex: myopia of 1D
  • Movement of red reflex with the plane mirror retinoscope: Emmetropia, hypermetropia, or myopia < 1D
  • Movement of red reflex against the plane mirror retinoscope: Myopia >1D
  • Oblique movement is seen in astigmatism.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presents with headache. He also has a family history of glaucoma. On examination, intraocular pressure was 23 and 24 mmHg in the right and left eye respectively. Iridocorneal angles were normal on gonioscopy. There was no visual field defects. Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition of the patient? (POAG- Primary open-angle glaucoma)

choices.text: Thin cornea is a risk factor for POAG development
Reducing IOP is effective in delaying the onset of POAG
Increased cup disc ratio is a risk factor for POAG development
Younger people are more at risk for progression to POAG than older people

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of the patient points towards ocular hypertension. Older people are more at risk of progression than younger people.

Ocular hypertension (OHT) is characterized only by raised intraocular pressure (IOP). The optic disc and visual fields are normal, with no evidence of angle closure.

Significant risk factors for the progression of ocular hypertension to primary open-angle glaucoma include the following:

  • Increased IOP
  • Increasing age
  • Increased cup-disc ratio
  • Thin cornea 
  • African-American race
  • Male gender
  • Associated heart disease

Evaluating the option statements on their own merit can help rule out the other 3 options and arrive at the correct answer, irrespective of solving the clinical scenario. At times, the clinical scenario may not really be essential to arriving at the answer.
