questions.text: Which is the most common cause of staphyloma at point D in the given image?
questions.solution:
Degenerative high axial myopia is the most common cause for posterior staphyloma (Point D)

Staphyloma:

  • It is an abnormal protrusion of the uveal tissue through a weak and thin portion of the cornea or sclera.
  • So, staphyloma is lined internally by uveal tissue and externally by weak cornea or sclera.
  • Types of Staphyloma:
    • Anterior staphyloma: It is characterized by ectasia of the pseudo-cornea, which occurs after the total sloughing of the cornea. It is lined internally by the iris and externally by the newly formed epithelium.
    • Intercalary staphyloma: This is located at the limbus and is lined by the root of the iris and the anterior-most part of the ciliary body
    • Ciliary staphyloma: It is characterized by ectasia of weak sclera lined by the ciliary body. This affects the ciliary zone, which includes the region up to 8 mm behind the limbus.
    • Equatorial staphyloma: This occurs at the equatorial region up to 14 mm behind the limbus of the eye.
    • Posterior staphyloma: This affects the posterior pole of the eye.
  • Note :
    • The most common cause for anterior staphyloma is sloughing corneal ulcer.
    • The most common cause for posterior staphyloma is degenerative high axial myopia.
  • In the image:
    • A: Intercalary staphyloma
    • B: Ciliary staphyloma
    • C: Equatorial staphyloma
    • D: Posterior staphyloma

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy was brought to the ophthalmology OPD with complaints of ropy discharge from his eyes. Moreover, on examination the following finding is present. What is the most probable diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The above image depicts cobblestone appearance, which is a papillary reaction in the palpebral conjunctiva, and also the presence of ropy discharge points towards the diagnosis of spring catarrh or vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC). No follicular reaction is seen.

  • It is also called as warm weather conjunctivitis
  • It primarily affects boys, and the onset is generally from the age of 5 years.
  • It is primarily a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction that is IgE mediated. It also involves type 4 hypersensitivity reaction.

Classical features of conjunctiva in VKC:

Palpebral VKC

  • Cobblestone papillae: upper tarsal conjunctiva
  • Associated with ropy discharge
  • Maxwell–Lyon sign: pseudomembrane formation of the upper lid when everted and exposed to heat 

Limbal VKC: Horner–Trantas spots are white dots consisting of eosinophils and epithelial debris in the limbal area. 

Corneal signs in VKC:

  • Shield ulcers
  • Vernal plaques
  • Subepithelial scarring
  • Pseudo-gerontoxon resembles arcus senilus; it has a cupid's bow outline

questions.text: You are conducting retrospective research on factors responsible for dry eye disorder.  As a part of your study, you are looking through the files in the clinic of dry eye patients. Which among the following patients would not be included in your study?

choices.text: A 26 year old patient showing decreased levels of lactoferrin in tear samples
A 20 year old patient showing tear film break up at 18-20 seconds
A 24 year old patient showing A pattern stain in Rose bengal staining
A 22 year old patient showing Schirmer test tear strip wet upto 9 mm

questions.solution:
A patient with tear film break up at 18-20 seconds is considered to be normal. All the other patients have dry eye.

Tear film break-up (BUT) time is the interval between a complete blink and the appearance of a first randomly distributed dry spot on the cornea. It is an indicator of the adequacy of the mucin component of tears.

Inference:

  • 15-35 seconds - normal
  • < 10 seconds- unstable tear film

Other options:

Option A: Tear samples can be assayed for the presence of markers known to be decreased (e.g. lactoferrin) or elevated (e.g. matrix metalloproteinase-9) in dry eye. This is known as tear constituent measurement. 

Option C: A patient with A pattern on Rose Bengal staining has severe dry eye. 

Option D: A patient with 9mm wet Schirmer strip has moderate dry eye. 

Related Pearl: Tear film tests used for the diagnosis of dry eye

Schirmer test

Inference 

  • 15 mm: Normal
  • 5-10 mm: Moderate keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS)
  • < 5 mm: Severe KCS

Tear film break up test (TBUT)

Inference 

  • 15-35 seconds: Normal
  • < 10 seconds: Unstable tear film

Inference

  • A pattern: Confluent staining → Severe KCS
  • B pattern: Extensive staining → Moderate KCS

Abnormal osmolarity is defined by 

  • An elevated reading, >300 mOsm/L, indicating loss of homeostasis, or
  • When the inter-eye difference is >8 mOsm/L, indicating instability of the tear film.

questions.text: You are a new intern posted in the department of ophthalmology. In the case file of a patient who had undergone a total penetrating keratoplasty, you see the ophthalmic examination findings saying that  'Khodadoust lines' are seen. In which of the conditions would you notice this finding?
questions.solution:
Khodadoust lines following penetrating keratoplasty are seen in a case of endothelial graft rejection. Khodadoust lines refer to a linear pattern of keratic precipitates associated with an area of inflammation at the graft margin.

Corneal graft rejection

The corneal graft is immunologically privileged, with an absence of blood vessels and lymphatics and the presence of relatively few antigen-presenting cells. Thus, they seldom are subject to graft failure or rejection. Predisposing factors for rejection include larger grafts >8 mm, infection, glaucoma, and previous keratoplasty.

Patients may have blurred vision, redness, photophobia, and pain. However, many patients remain asymptomatic until rejection is established. Corneal graft rejection can be of four types:

  • Epithelial rejection - elevated level of epithelium is noticed. 
  • Sub-epithelial rejection - usually due to residual adenoviral infection. These form infiltrative opacities called Krachmer spots. 
  • Stromal rejection - these present with deeper haziness.
  • Endothelial rejection - These are characterized by Khodadoust lines. It is the most common form of graft rejection leading to failure.

Stromal edema is indicative of graft failure and the presentation is almost always akin to anterior uveitis.

questions.text: A 38-year-old lady is a known case of diabetes and is on insulin for the last 8 years. Her sugars are poorly controlled and now she complains of hazy vision. What type of cataract will be characteristically noted in her eyes?
questions.solution:
The typical appearance of a diabetic cataract is a snowflake cataract.

Hyperglycemia is reflected in a high level of glucose in the aqueous humor, which diffuses into the lens. Here, glucose is metabolized into sorbitol, which accumulates within the lens, resulting in secondary osmotic overhydration.

questions.text: A 40-year-old diabetic patient presented with the ​squint. On examination, the secondary deviation was found to be more than the primary deviation. Forced duction test is negative. Which of the following types of squint is most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of paralytic squint. It is characterized by the presence of secondary deviation more than the primary deviation and a negative forced duction test.

The squint may be either comitant or incomitant.

  • Comitant squint: The angle of squint measured is same in all gazes. 
  • Incomitant squint: The angle of squint measured is different in different gazes. 

The differences between comitant and incomitant squint are shown in the table below:

Features Comitant squint Incomitant squint
Magnitude of squint Same in all gazes Varies with the gaze
Diplopia Absent Present
Ocular movements Full Restricted
False projection Absent Present
Abnormal head posture Absent Present
Secondary deviation Equal to primary deviation More than primary deviation

The incomitant squint is further divided into two main types: Paralytic and restrictive.

Paralytic squint occurs due to the paralysis of extraocular muscle while restrictive squint is due to the mechanical restriction caused by tight or fibrosed muscle.

Forced duction test(FDT) differentiates between these two types. In this test, the eye is moved mechanically with the help of a forceps.

  • The test is negative if there is no resistance to the movement. It is seen in a paralytic squint.
  • The test is positive if there is resistance to the movement. It is seen in a restrictive squint.

questions.text: A patient presents with a sudden painless loss of vision in his right eye. On fundus examination, the following finding was seen. Which among the following conditions is likely?
questions.solution:
The image shows a splashed sauce appearance which is characteristic of central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO). 

CRVO refers to sudden or acute occlusion of the central retinal vein. It presents with a sudden loss of vision. On examination, a relative afferent pupillary defect is present.

Funduscopy shows engorged and tortuous retinal veins, massive retinal hemorrhages with splashed tomato appearance, and cotton wool spots. The disc is edematous and hyperemic. Changes that occur later include neovascularization at the disc or periphery with pigmentary changes at the macula.

Complications:

  • Rubeosis iridis or neovascularization of the iris
  • Neovascular glaucoma (NVG) or 100 day glaucoma
  • Vitreous hemorrhage

100-day glaucoma is a type of neovascular glaucoma (NVG) and is so-called because it typically develops 3 months after the episode of CRVO.

Other options:

Option A- The funduscopy findings in central retinal artery occlusion include pale retina, thread-like arteries, a cherry-red spot in the macula, and cattle trucking (segmentation of blood in the retinal veins). It is shown below.

Option C: The funduscopy in retinal detachment shows detachment of fovea and macula, as shown below.

Option D: Fundoscopy changes in retinitis pigmentosa include perivascular retinal hyperpigmentation, narrow retinal arterioles, atrophy of retinal pigment epithelium, and disc pallor. It is shown below.
